item.title: The First Descendant: How to Farm Focus on Electric Module
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Where To Farm Focus On Electric Module In The First Descendant
  • What Does Focus On Electric Module Do In The First Descendant?

The First Descendant has many different characters to play, and each of them can be made even better with the right Modules equipped. Players will be replaying missions to get all the Modules they need to overcome the end-game content.

Even if Bunny is not a character that a player uses, they should consider getting the Focus on Electric Module and pairing it with her — as this can help any player farm the items they want at a much faster rate.

Where To Farm Focus On Electric Module In The First Descendant

Players who are still making their way through the story will see that each mission has its own list of potential drops — such as the game’s various Modules. Seeing a module they want listed on several missions can make players wonder what the best approach to farming it is. Luckily, players will be able to find the perfect spot to farm this module as soon as the second area they unlock, the Sterile Land. Once they unlock this location, they should speed past all the purple mission markers and then play out any incomplete yellow missions. Once all of this is done, they will be able to launch into the Sterile Lands with the world set to Hard . Doing so will increase the likelihood of Focus on Electric dropping while they play.

Once the game is set to Hard , go to the Restricted Zone location of Sterile Land . At this location will be a Void Mission that will be able to drop this Module. Using a character that can clear enemies in record time will allow players to start the mission, wipe out all enemies, and repeat. Whenever you set out on a Void Mission, be sure you bring the right element for the job, this is where having friends with different characters can help out a lot.

What Does Focus On Electric Module Do In The First Descendant?

This Module is a Descendant Module , meaning it will not be as good on some characters as it is on others. It is also one of the best possible modules that a player can put on their Bunny or their Ultimate Bunny after unlocking her. The Focus On Electric Module will increase the Electric Skill Power and Skill Cooldown of the Descendant it is equipped to.

For a character like Bunny, this is a Module they will want to upgrade as soon as they can to make clearing missions even faster, which will in turn make it much faster for players to farm resources and get the items they want thanks to how her kit works. This explains why players see so many max-level Bunnies that wipe out every single enemy they run past without even using any of their weapons. All players will be able to unlock Bunny, so all players should invest in getting this Module to speed up their farming game, regardless of who their preferred Descendants of choice are.

item.title: 10 Best Fantasy Games With Base Building, Ranked
item.description:
Games that allow players to build a base are always popular due to their replayability and customizable gameplay. Base-building games show up in a variety of genres, from simulation to horror and even sci-fi. However, for many gamers, fantasy base-building games are the favorite.

Games in this subgenre are best when they are relaxed in pace, methodical, and have a variety of building pieces and systems for gamers to play around with. Whether players are on the hunt for something new to play, or curious whether their favorite game has made it here, here are some of the best fantasy base-building games by these criteria.

10 Minecraft (Modded)

A Trailblazer For The Genre

The fantasy elements of Minecraft may be light at times, but this titan of the base-building genre can't be ignored. Not only is it one of the first games to experiment with total building freedom, but it boasts one of the most active modding communities in the world, giving gamers a chance to mod in more fantasy-themed gameplay.

In this bare-bones title, players can build anything of their dreams at any location, provided they have the patience. Build any structure from cubes of various colors and textures, with the only limit being their imagination. Players can even make complex quasi-electric machines, enchant their weapons with magic buffs, and brew potions.

9 Mind Over Magic

Build A School Of Witchcraft & Wizardry

Mind over Magic is a lesser-known game that entered early access in late 2023. This game is from Klei, the same developer as Don't Starve , Don't Starve Together , Rotwood , and Oxygen Not Included . In Mind over Magic , players are the founders of a school of witchcraft and wizardry. Manage the studies of students, design and build the school, and explore the dark secrets below in this colony management-oriented base builder.

While this game is still in early access, and therefore currently lacks the polish and complexity of Klei's other projects, the reputation of the developer and its already promising state make Mind Over Magic a game to watch. When combined with the game's very reasonable price tag, Mind Over Magic is a great pickup for fans of the genre.

8 Nightingale

Explore The Fairytale World Of Nightingale

Nightingale is a trippy entry into the survival crafting genre, where players become Reamwalkers to explore the Fae Realm of Nightingale . Players must fight mystical enemies, build shelters, and collect information to open portals deeper into the realms.

The game is in early access, but the developer has been very receptive to community feedback and making great progress at fleshing out some of Nightingale's mechanics. Nightingale has a good foundation and unique concept that has the chance to make this a great game. Its modest price point is well worth the current content provided, and it looks to be heading toward a fantastic place.

7 Valheim

Fight Your Way Into Valhalla

Valheim , another entry into the survival crafting genre, is heavily inspired by Nordic folklore. With friends, players can become the realm's greatest warriors, sent to Valheim to prove their worth to Odin and the Valkyries and crush the forces of evil. Build a base, craft weapons, and fight dangerous monsters of mythical fame.

Due to its lore and atmospheric world, this game has a loyal following. Defeating each of the game's eleven bosses gives players access to Forsaken Powers, each of which increases the player's strength for their next encounter, and is perfect for players seeking out a demigod power fantasy. The building system in Valheim is modular, meaning most buildings look similar until they are customized with decor, but the lore more than makes up for this shortcoming.

6 Enshrouded

Build A Castle & Find The Truth

In Enshrouded , players begin as one of the last of the Flameborn. The Flameborn are a nearly extinct race of people who, through their own arrogance, unleashed a corrupting fog across the land known as the Shroud. One of the main goals of this game is to find out what happened and restore a semblance of order to the land. The player's main obstacle in doing so is the living beings that come into contact with the fog. Most become horrifying monsters, which players will need to fight and protect themselves from.

The best method of protecting important resources from the influence of the Shroud is to build a base, which players can do with significant customization. Not only is the location up to the player but buildings are constructed in small blocks with completely flexible window and door placement along with an intuitive set of tools and controls.

5 Age of Darkness: Final Stand

Push Back The Creeping Veil

Age of Darkness: Final Stand is a top-down tower defense game with base-building elements. Players will command the armies of the last bastion of Humanity, attempting to fight back hordes of nightmarish creatures while expanding. Encouraging NPCs to collect resources and deciding how to lay out defenses are crucial aspects of the game, making it strangely similar to a city builder.

Each map is procedurally generated, and initially covered in a fog of war mechanic called the veil. This means players will need to be flexible when building their bases, and no two playthroughs will be the same. While the primary objective is, of course, survival, the winning condition of Age of Darkness: Final Stand is to completely drive back the veil, so there will be a lot of building to do.

4 Cult of the Lamb

Become An Adorable Cult Leader

Cult of the Lamb is a cross between a rogue-like combat game and an adorable city-building and planning game. Players become the fluffy, villainous cult leader of their dreams and design the settlement where their cultists live. This can include housing, belief systems, and even decorations.

As for the fantasy elements, aside from all characters being talking animals, gods in this realm are tangible and dangerous. Fight through various supernatural bosses, conduct strange rituals, and even feed a monster of the deep. With several free expansions under the game's belt, this title has plenty of content to explore.

3 Dungeons 3

Gloriously Sarcastic & Irreverent

Dungeons 3 is the sequel to the successful Dungeons franchise, which recently received another title ( Dungeons 4) . Despite not being the newest entry in the franchise, few can disagree that the humor and level design of this strategy-based building game makes it a joy to play. In Dungeons 3 , players act as the hand of evil, building an outpost in each level, growing an army, and taking on those pesky forces of good.

As a reward for each new victory, players can enjoy the sarcastic and lighthearted story of the Dark Elf Thalia, convert heroes to the side of darkness, and build ever more complex underground paradises. Additionally, this title won't break the bank, as it is a little on the older side and often quite discounted.

2 REKA

Become Baba Yaga's Apprentice

In REKA , gamers play as the young apprentice of the legendary witch Baba Yaga. Gather ingredients, craft, decorate a walking house, and brew potions. This is a cozy, story-driven game where players will primarily be challenged with exploration and moral dilemmas, not combat.

REKA is easily the most promising of the early-access games here in terms of uniqueness and richness alone. While German developer Emberstorm Entertainment is still expanding the crafting system and character customization options, the world is very fleshed out with lore and character. This hard work has paid off as well - REKA was the recipient of the Most Anticipated Game and Critics' Choice awards at Indie Cup Germany'23.

1 V Rising

Become The Vampire Overlord Of Your Dreams

V Rising clocks in as first on the list of fantasy base-building games due to its incredibly detailed base-building, rich fantasy world, and roleplay potential. In V Rising , players are recently awakened vampires amassing the power to usurp Dracula himself, and for that, they'll obviously need a gothic castle of their own.

Castles are built on plots of land that dot the map, with nearly 200 different potential locations. Once players have selected a spot, they'll be able to build the castle piece by piece with resources... liberated ... from nearby townsfolk. The building potential is endless, and the community adores showing off their best base builds as castle tours like the one by Spiteful Crow on YouTube.

item.title: Baldur's Gate 3: Funniest Camp Supplies
item.description:
In Baldur’s Gate 3 , the party can only truck along for so long before they need to hunker down for the night. In classic Dungeons & Dragons fashion, this takes the form of taking a Long Rest, where companions can sleep, have a much-needed meal, and have their mortal wounds magically disappear overnight.

But in order to set up camp, one must have supplies. Thankfully, there are plenty of crates, barrels, vases, and vendors where players can get the necessary provisions. Most of the time, these are nondescript foodstuffs, but Larian Studios can’t help but throw in fun details wherever possible. Here are some camp supplies that are more fun than they had any right to be.

7 Suspicious Meat

Try Not To Think About It

Cannibalism is frowned upon in most Sword Coast societies, but not all of them. Several evil lairs throughout the game stock their kitchen tents with all manner of putrid grub. Some of them, like the goblin camp, even have the roasted remains of dwarven body parts. Thankfully, the main party would never stoop so low, no matter how hungry. Right?

There’s no definitive answer for what the Suspicious Meat is. Players can do what the in-game description suggests and just choose to believe it’s just the thigh of one especially lanky pig. But if some players preferred selling this meat hunk off to a less scrupulous vendor, well, there’s no shame in that.

6 Salami

Who Has Done the Salami-Only Run?

Baldur’s Gate 3 has plenty of dried, salted, and cured meats for the carnivorous companion. Looting someone’s cupboard is bound to turn up plenty of dried sausages and hams. But the Salami is a special case. It holds the distinction of being the only camp supplies that doubles as a melee weapon.

That’s right: players can give a Salami to a companion to swing like a club. It doesn’t do an impressive amount of damage or anything. But the simple fact that Larian Studios even thought of this is nothing short of amazing. Some people dip their weapons in poison. Others dip them in mustard.

5 Alcohol

Nothing Like Adventuring While Hungover

The Sword Coast has an impressive selection of wines, beers, and other alcoholic beverages, far too many to list here. From the finest vintages from Rosymorn Monastery to the Baldurian equivalent of cheap box wine, the game developers sure had fun thinking of ways this continent likes to booze it up.

Of course, there’s nothing wrong with popping open a bottle or two with the regular food rations during a Long Rest. However, the player can also choose to only use alcohol for the night’s provisions. This causes the party to wake up still inebriated from the night before. Thisobald Thorm would be proud.

4 Neogi Claws & Rolls

The Feast of Champions, Seasoned With Spite

It’s fun to learn about the cuisine of other cultures, especially when they exist in other planes of existence. The githyanki are a warmongering people who traverse the Astral Plane for worlds to plunder and conquer. They’ve slaughtered countless aberrations and found many tasty uses for the spoils of battle.

Gamers who have never seen a neogi before should count themselves lucky. These monsters would be the ugliest creatures in the game, even more than the squid-faced mind flayers. Hopefully, neogi meat tastes better than it looks. At least Lae’zel seems to like it.

3 Owlbear Egg

Plenty of Ways To Prepare It

Stumble into the wrong cave in Act 1, and players will come across one angry mother owlbear. After her demise at the hands of some goblins (or the player), she leaves behind one adorable cub and one unhatched egg.

Now, players could simply fry up the world’s biggest omelet during a Long Rest. Or they could pass it off as a githyanki egg for a quest in Act 1. For extra mileage, players could then kill the quest-giver or simply steal the owlbear egg back after getting the quest reward.

2 Bex’s Handmade Cookies

Best Quest Reward Ever

Some quest-givers don’t have much to offer, and that’s okay. For many of the tiefling refugees players encounter throughout the game, all they can offer is a hearty thanks and maybe a small crowdsourced collection of gold. For good-aligned players, that’s all they could ask for.

But for Bex, even though she only has the clothes on her back and little else, thanks just isn’t enough. If players manage to rescue the love of her life from Moonrise Towers, she rewards them the only way she can: a fresh tray of piping-hot cookies. A job well done never felt so sweet.

1 Grilled Miniature Giant Space Hamster

Don’t Look, Boo!

Minsc insists that his travel companion Boo is no normal hamster, but a miniature version of giant space hamsters from the Astral Plane. While this is mostly just a running gag for laughs, there are some hints throughout the game that he might actually be right.

The most morbid of these hints is this skewered delicacy right here. Lae’zel did hint that miniature giant space hamsters did exist, but who knew the gith liked to serve them up kebab-style? Perhaps Boo should make like a certain vampire and avoid pointy sticks for the time being.

item.title: 8 Largest Dragons In FromSoftware Games, Ranked By Size
item.description:
Dragons have always captured the imagination of fantasy fans; there's something both majestic and terrifying about these legendary creatures found in various cultures worldwide. Dragons are also a staple in gaming, appearing in countless titles across different genres. Since the original Demon's Souls , FromSoftware has consistently included dragons in their Soulsborne games, with each new entry surpassing the last in terms of complexity, spectacle, and excitement in dragon boss fights.

However, it's not just the studio's boss battles against dragons like Bayle The Dread, Lichdragon Fortissax, The Slumbering Dragon Sinh, Black Dragon Kalameet, Dragonlord Placidusax, or Ancient Dragon Lansseax that have captivated fans. Often, some of the most intriguing scaled creatures in the developer's games aren't the ones players fight. In many cases, in games like Elden Ring or Dark Souls 3 , the biggest and most impressive dragons are encountered as inactive corpses or even elements of the landscape. This list will rank the largest dragons ever encountered in FromSoftware's fantasy games.

8 Darkeater Midir (Dark Souls 3: The Ringed City)

80 Meters Long

Probably one of the most challenging and iconic dragon boss fights in FromSoftware's history, Darkeater Midir stands as the smallest dragon on this list. Measuring about 80 meters from nose to tail, Midir is one of the largest dragons players can actually face in combat, but not the biggest overall.

A descendant of the Archdragons raised by the gods, Darkeater Midir is encountered in Dark Souls 3: The Ringed City DLC. The actual battle with this dragon is a secret optional fight that players don't need to endure to complete the game. However, if they choose to, they better be prepared for one of the toughest and most unforgiving encounters in all of Dark Souls 3 . Midir's long and dangerous melee combos, devastating bites, and fire-breathing attacks — along with the infamous laser display in the second half of the fight — can end most players in just a hit or two.

7 Ancient Dragon (Dark Souls 2)

90 Meters Long

The Ancient Dragon is one of the largest bosses in Dark Souls 2 and is slightly bigger than Darkeater Midir. Players are not obligated to kill the Ancient Dragon when they find him at the top of the Dragon Shrine and can simply converse with him telepathically before moving on. Alternatively, they can choose to engage in battle with this colossal creature.

However, the fight against this behemoth is much easier than you might expect and is not as challenging as the previous entry on this list. Despite the Ancient Dragon having the largest health pool in the entire game (even larger than Midir's), it is very large and slow, making evading most of its attacks relatively easy. If players are careful, they can prevail and overcome this menacing opponent with relative ease.

6 Divine Dragon (Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice)

152 Meters Long

Here's where things start to ramp up. While Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice doesn't offer many boss fights against non-human enemies, the battle against the Divine Dragon, also known as Dragon of the Everblossom, is an exception, and it's extremely memorable and cinematic. Found at the Fountainhead Palace, this boss battle is a classic staged encounter that doesn't require players to fight the creature in a typical FromSoftware boss fashion — instead, players must perform a series of special steps/sequences to complete this spectacular battle.

This dragon has a serpentine design typical of Japanese dragons, which are conventionally connected to water, and resembles a giant serpent with legs. It isn't FromSoftware's largest, but its length is impressive at 152 meters. For comparison, it is the same size as Vhagar from House of the Dragon and slightly bigger than Smaug from the Hobbit trilogy, who is 130 meters long.

5 Archdragon Corpse (Dark Souls 3)

166 Meters Long

The first dragon on this list that appears to be long gone is the unknown Archdragon corpse in Dark Souls 3 , which players can see from afar when exploring the game's secret area, Archdragon Peak. We don't know much about this colossal creature, but fan measurements estimate the corpse to be 166 meters long.

For comparison, King Ghidorah's height in Godzilla: King of the Monsters is 160 meters, making the two approximately the same size. Fighting a dragon twice the size of Darkeater Midir would have been quite a spectacle in Dark Souls 3 , but perhaps it is too massive to be killed by mere mortals.

4 Dragon God (Demon's Souls)

182 Meters Long

Dragon God appeared in the very first Soulsborne game by FromSoftware ( Demon's Souls ) and was considered the largest of the dragons created by the studio for years until Elden Ring came out. Found in the Underground Temple, Dragon God is truly enormous at 182 meters long and is capable of instantly killing the player's character. For comparison, Dragon God is almost the size of Godzilla from the latest Monsterverse movies, where the Kaiju is estimated to be 177 meters long.

Fighting Dragon God isn't a direct showdown like many other fights. Instead of trying to damage this colossal creature with their weapons, players have to avoid the dragon's attacks and reach two large ballistae to weaken him. Only after that can you deliver the finishing blow to his weak point on the head.

3 Elder Dragon Greyoll (Elden Ring)

182 Meters Long

The last dragon on this list that players can actually fight is the massive Elder Dragon Greyoll, encountered in the Dragonbarrow region of Caelid in Elden Ring . This dragon is comparable in size to Dragon God and can be seen from afar when exploring the surrounding lands. It is a sight to behold, but the fight with this one is rather special, as the dragon itself is too ancient — and decrepit with Scarlet Rot — to directly oppose the player.

Instead of fighting Greyoll, players can slaughter all five lesser dragons that are protecting it, which in turn will finish off this giant dragon. Alternatively, there's a safe spot near Greyoll where players can damage it without the need to fight all the smaller dragons, who will die as soon as Greyoll itself is killed. Once you know this trick, killing Elder Dragon Greyoll is easy — even for early-game characters — and will reward players with a great amount of runes to level up their Tarnished quickly. While quite easy to pull off, it is a time-consuming endeavor, as Greyoll has an enormous health pool (87,664 HP) — one of the biggest of all Elden Ring bosses.

2 Ancient Dragon Gransax (Elden Ring)

328 Meters Long

Here comes another point on this list where things get truly colossal. Ancient Dragon Gransax in Elden Ring is almost twice as big as Dragon God or Elder Dragon Greyoll, and is another spectacular dragon in FromSoftware's games that players encounter already dead and don't have to fight.

At a massive 328 meters, Ancient Dragon Gransax attacked Leyndell, the Royal Capital, marking the first time the city's walls failed to protect it. Its corpse now covers a large part of the capital, creating an unforgettable sight — and unorthodox way to traverse the city's ruins — when exploring one of the most beautiful locations the studio has ever created.

1 Unknown Colossal Dragon Corpse (Elden Ring: Shadow Of The Erdtree)

392 Meters Long

With the release of the Shadow of the Erdtree expansion for Elden Ring , a new record-breaking dragon was found (via YT Zullie the Witch) among all the dragons that ever appeared in FromSoftware games. This colossal corpse, visible on the Land of Shadows' map above the Finger Ruins of the Rhia region, measures about 392 meters, significantly larger even than Ancient Dragon Gransax.

Very little is known about this unnamed dragon corpse at this point. The fact that its model is just an enlarged version of the common lesser dragons from Elden Ring may suggest there isn't much history or lore behind it. Still, there might be more to this creature that has not yet been uncovered. For now, though, it is undoubtedly the largest dragon FromSoftware has ever put in their games, and it is unlikely to be surpassed for some time.

item.title: Honkai Star Rail - How To Complete Clockwork: Oksana And Get Hidden Achievements
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Where In Penacony Can You Find Oksana
  • What Do You Need To Do For Oksana
  • How To Unlock Oksana's Hidden Achievements In Penacony

Oksana is a Penacony NPC from Honkai Star Rail with three hidden achievements tied to her mini quest. These three quests, “ Lord of War ”, “ Better Late Than Never ”, and “ Dishonored Legacy ” are exclusive to each other. Getting one means locking out the other achievements, but these only count as one achievement on the tracker.

Earning any of these achievements is tied to player choices within the quest “Clockwork: Oksana”. Luckily for players, their choice sat the end is the deciding factor for what achievement they’ll unlock, and no other choice. Otherwise, they only need to follow the steps outlined in the quest.

Where In Penacony Can You Find Oksana

Oksana can be found at Clock Studios Theme Park , at the ticket lobby to the right of the Screening Area Entrance Space Anchor. The area is accessible after clearing the Trailblaze Mission “Why Do the Heathen Rage”. Since players are immediately teleported into Acheron’s POV after completing the mission, they have to teleport to Clock Studios Theme Park immediately afterward.

Once the area is unlocked, find Oksana off the Screening Area entrance beside a plant. Talk to her and activate Clockwork to unlock her Emo Dial . A “Happy” Gear is required to get her to open up.

After tuning, Oksana will ask the player to help her. Select any of the three options . Oksana will then ask the player to fetch a package from the corner of the theme park and deliver it to a contact.

What Do You Need To Do For Oksana

Oksana’s toy package is located south of the Screening Area. Use the Hanu Gang Base Space Anchor at F2 level. Follow the map and find the toy on the shelf in the street corner.

Afterward, open the map to Golden Hour. Teleport to the Peppy Pepeshi’s Salon Space Anchor on F1 and follow the quest marker up the stairs. The contact is hiding behind a column right beside a short flight of stairs.

Go back to the Screening Area and find Oksana with a Mysterious Stranger. Confront Oksana about their conversation. Then, teleport to the Theme Park Entrance Space Anchor on F1 to the right of the Screening Area and talk to the Mysterious Stranger again.

How To Unlock Oksana's Hidden Achievements In Penacony

At this point, players can decide Oksana’s fate. They can confront her and turn her in , accept her bribe , or take a third option . All options will reward the player with 5 Star Jades through the corresponding hidden achievement.

Lord Of War Hidden Achievement

“Lord of War” is the easiest achievement to unlock. Players only need to go back to Oksana and confront her over her weapon smuggling scheme. They must then select “ You can keep your filthy blood money .” when bribed and watch Woolsey and the Bloodhounds take Oksana away.

Better Late Than Never

“Better Late Than Never” takes a few more steps. After confronting Oksana, select “ That’s what I meant .” to accept her bribe. When the game loads in after Oksana leaves, teleport to the Theme Park Entrance then follow the marker to Woolsey and report Oksana.

Dishonored Legacy

“Dishonored Legacy” takes the other path to the last choice in “Better Late Than Never”. Instead of seeking Woolsey out, players must teleport out of Clock Studios Theme Park. The hidden achievement is unlocked after getting away with Oksana’s in-story bribe.
